channel.title: XML on Scott's Weblog
channel.description: Recent content in XML on Scott's Weblog

item.title: Using Paw to Launch an EC2 Instance via API Calls
item.description: Last week I wrote a post on using Postman to launch an EC2 instance via API calls. Postman is a cross-platform application, so while my post was centered around Postman on Linux (Ubuntu, specifically) the steps should be very similar—if not exactly the same—when using Postman on other platforms. Users of macOS, however, have another option: a macOS-specific peer to Postman named Paw. In this post, I’ll walk through using Paw to issue API requests to AWS to launch an EC2 instance.

item.title: Using Postman to Launch an EC2 Instance via API Calls
item.description: As I mentioned in this post on region and endpoint match in AWS API requests, exploring the AWS APIs is something I’ve been doing off and on for several months. There’s a couple reasons for this; I’ll go into those in a bit more detail shortly. In any case, I’ve been exploring the APIs using Postman (when on Linux) and Paw (when on macOS), and in this post I’ll share how to use Postman to launch an EC2 instance via API calls.

item.title: Opening Web Internet Location Files on Ubuntu
item.description: As part of my effort to make myself and my workflows more “cross-platform friendly,” I’ve been revisiting certain aspects of how I do things. One of the things I’m reviewing is how I capture—and later review—posts or articles on the web. On macOS, I would run an AppleScript that generated a .webloc file (aka an Internet location file). This is an XML file that macOS understands. However, Linux doesn’t natively understand these files, so today I came up with a solution to reading .
